Key Match Events: Darius Garland led Cleveland with 40 points and nine assists.
The Raptors started aggressively, forcing several key turnovers and making timely buckets in the early going.
Chris Boucher came off the bench and made all his four attempts, including 3-for-3 from beyond the arc, to help Toronto take a 33-27 lead after the first quarter.
The Cavaliers stretched their winning streak to 12 games.
The Cavaliers went 20-for-25 from the free-throw line, while the Raptors were 6-for-13.
The Cavaliers had 16 offensive rebounds compared to the Raptors' 9.
Pre-Game Insights: Before facing the Cleveland Cavaliers, Raptors head coach Darko Rajakovic said how important it is for struggling teams like his to play against the best teams.
The Cavaliers are on the second leg of back-to-back games, while the Raptors are also dealing with fatigue.
The Cavaliers selected Evan Mobley third in the 2021 draft, while the Raptors picked Scottie Barnes fourth.
Post-Match Reflections: Rajakovic said, 'We did not get the win tonight but I'm really proud of how our guys cheered for each other, how they competed, how they gave it all they had tonight.'
Rajakovic lamented the free-throw disparity and offensive rebounding advantage of the Cavaliers.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Cavaliers came into the game with the best record in the entire league.
This was the 11th head-to-head game between Evan Mobley and Scottie Barnes, with neither player having a clear advantage.
Ochai Agbaji missed his first game of the season due to a left hip bruise.
The Raptors were also without rookies Jonathan Mogbo and Jamison Battle, who are on assignment with the 905, along with Eugene Omuruyi.
Bruce Brown was a late scratch with a left knee injury.
